docs.lead_paragraph: I honestly meant to write about something other than health care for my Thursday column. Afghanistan, perhaps. Or Iran. Or education. Or deworming or obstetric fistula or social entrepreneurs or a million other columns waiting to be written. But with the health reform package at risk of being defeated -- I would actually bet that it'll pass, but I wouldn't give odds -- I ended up writing about health again for today's column. If health reform were to go down to defeat this year, it might be many more years before it could be revived and that would be unbearably sad.
docs.abstract: Health care seems the priority of the moment, so that's what I wrote my Thursday column about.
docs.snippet: Health care seems the priority of the moment, so that's what I wrote my Thursday column about.

docs.lead_paragraph: According to the new Congressional Budget Office analysis, the Senate Finance Committee's health care legislation would cost $829 billion to provide insurance coverage to millions of Americans. But over 10 years, it would also reduce federal deficits by $81 billion.

headline.main: Reduce the Deficit by Spending $829 Billion. Huh?

docs.abstract: How can you spend $829 billion and reduce the federal deficits by $81 billion?
docs.snippet: How can you spend $829 billion and reduce the federal deficits by $81 billion?

docs.lead_paragraph: Bob Dole, the one-time Republican leader in the Senate, and Tom Daschle, the one-time Democratic leader, issued a joint statement today in which they said they supported the Democrats' attempt to overhaul the health care system.

headline.main: Dole and Daschle Endorse a Health Care Overhaul

docs.abstract: Two former Congressional leaders lend their support to Democratic efforts to revamp health care.
docs.snippet: Two former Congressional leaders lend their support to Democratic efforts to revamp health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hospital lobbyists said Wednesday that the Congressional Budget Office's analysis of the Senate Finance Committee's health legislation indicated that the committee had not yet delivered on a deal they made with panel's chairman, Max Baucus, and the White House for their support.

headline.main: Hospital Lobbyists Say Baucus Has Not Yet Lived Up to Their Deal

docs.abstract: Hospital lobbyists say the Senate Finance Committee has not delivered on its promise to insure at least 94 percent of America's residents.
docs.snippet: Hospital lobbyists say the Senate Finance Committee has not delivered on its promise to insure at least 94 percent of America's residents.

docs.lead_paragraph: The long-awaited budget analysis of a pending Senate health care bill indicates that the legislation would meet President Obama's cost target and would reduce future federal deficits by a deeper amount than previously projected.

headline.main: Analysis Sees Baucus Health Bill Meeting Obama's Cost and Deficit Targets

docs.abstract: The Senate Finance Committee's health care legislation, as amended during seven days of debate, would cost a projected $829 billion over 10 years -- up from $774 billion, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
docs.snippet: The Senate Finance Committee's health care legislation, as amended during seven days of debate, would cost a projected $829 billion over 10 years -- up from $774 billion, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: William Dow is a health economics professor at the University of California, Berkeley, who served with the Council of Economic Advisers under former President George W. Bush. He is studying Healthy San Francisco, the city's effort to provide health care to the uninsured. He spoke with freelance writer Anne Underwood.

headline.main: In San Francisco, Another Kind of Public Option

docs.abstract: San Francisco's groundbreaking effort to extend health care to the uninsured may offer lessons to the rest of the nation.
docs.snippet: San Francisco's groundbreaking effort to extend health care to the uninsured may offer lessons to the rest of the nation.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Senate Finance Committee - and the rest of us - anxiously await a new Congressional Budget Office cost analysis of the big health care legislation, an analysis of the bill by a panel of experts suggests there are still a number of additional steps that could be taken to tamp down long-term health care costs.

headline.main: Experts Say Baucus Plan Slows Spending but Could Do More

docs.abstract: A new cost analysis of the Baucus bill by outside experts suggests there are still a number of additional steps that could be taken to tamp down long-term health care costs.
docs.snippet: A new cost analysis of the Baucus bill by outside experts suggests there are still a number of additional steps that could be taken to tamp down long-term health care costs.

headline.main: Answers About New York's Street Vendors

docs.lead_paragraph: Verisk Analytics, the insurance data specialist, raised $1.88 billion in its initial public offering Tuesday, after shares priced higher than expected, Bloomberg News reported.
